title: R40215
content: During a confirmation hearing in January 2009, OMB Director-designate Peter Orszag discussed plans for oversight of the economic stimulus package. He proposed creating a special oversight board chaired by a Chief Performance Officer to review and address problems. The Obama Administration planned to establish an oversight board chaired by a Chief Performance Officer to review problems related to contracts and financial information. They also intended to create a website, Recovery.gov, to provide transparency on stimulus legislation. The Obama Administration established Recovery.gov to provide transparency on stimulus legislation and financial information about contracts. An oversight board was created to root out waste and inefficiency in government spending. Numerous oversight provisions were included in economic stimulus legislation. The House and Senate included oversight provisions in economic stimulus legislation to address waste and inefficiency in government spending. The federal government is seen as a system of "nested" oversight, with multiple entities engaging in simultaneous oversight activities. Congress oversees the President and agencies, including the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Inspectors general and congressional support agencies play a role in oversight as well. Within the federal government, multiple entities engage in oversight activities. Congress oversees the President, agencies, and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Inspectors general and agencies like the Government Accountability Office (GAO) assist in oversight. OMB is responsible for managing and overseeing various agencies, while agencies also monitor their own activities as mandated by Congress. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) plays a key role in overseeing agencies' activities, ensuring compliance with laws and regulations, and preventing fraud.
